questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents with pruritic, erythematous, scaly lesions over the flexor aspect of her forearm, as shown in the image. She reports a history of dry skin since childhood. Her mother has asthma, and her brother suffers from allergic rhinitis. Based on the clinical image and history, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of pruritic, scaly, erythematous flexural lesions with a personal and family history of atopy strongly points toward atopic dermatitis.

Atopic Dermatitis:

  • Chronic, relapsing, inflammatory skin condition.
  • Characterised by intense itching.
  • Typically begins in early childhood (usually <2 years).
  • Variable presentation across age groups and ethnicities.
  • Associated with other atopic conditions (e.g., asthma, allergic rhinitis).
  • No specific diagnostic test (except skin biopsy in rare cases).
  • Clinical Features:
    • Itching
    • Macular erythema
    • Papules or papulovesicles
    • Eczematous areas with:
      • Crusting
      • Lichenification
      • Excoriation
    • Hyper- or hypopigmentation
    • Dry skin
    • Secondary infections
    • Distribution:
      • Flexural areas (common in children and adults)
      • Non-flexural involvement (more common in infants and people with skin of colour)
  • UK Diagnostic Criteria for Atopic Eczema:
    • Must have:
      • Itchy skin condition within the last 12 months
    • Plus 3 or more of the following:
      1. Onset before age 2
      2. History of flexural involvement
      3. History of generally dry skin
      4. Personal history of other atopic diseases
      5. Visible flexural dermatitis

Explanation of other options:

Seborrhoeic dermatitis (Option A): Typically affects sebaceous-rich areas like the scalp, face (nasolabial folds), chest, and behind the ears, presenting with greasy, yellowish scales. It is not associated with flexural involvement or a family history of atopy, making it unlikely in this case.

Allergic contact dermatitis (Option C): Caused by a type IV hypersensitivity reaction to an external allergen, it presents with acute, well-demarcated erythematous lesions, often with vesicles, localized to the contact site. It lacks the chronic, relapsing nature and familial atopic history seen in atopic dermatitis.

Erysipelas (Option D): An acute bacterial skin infection (usually due to Streptococcus) that presents with a sharply demarcated, tender, warm, and swollen red plaque, often with fever, not chronic, itchy, or scaly like in this case.

questions.text: A patient presents with a chronic scaly skin condition, characterized by erythematous plaques covered with thick silvery scales. New lesions have appeared along sites of scratching and minor trauma, as shown in the image. Which of the following clinical signs is most closely associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
The clinical image and history are consistent with psoriasis, specifically the development of lesions along lines of trauma, a response known as the isomorphic phenomenon, or Koebner phenomenon. This reaction occurs when new psoriatic plaques form at sites of skin injury such as cuts, scratches, or pressure areas.

Koebner Phenomenon (Isomorphic Phenomenon)


  • Describes the appearance of new skin lesions typical of a pre-existing condition at sites of trauma (e.g., scratches, pressure, or surgical scars).
  • Commonly seen in psoriasis, where linear lesions may appear following minor injuries.
  • The phenomenon typically follows an "all-or-none" pattern in affected individuals.

Explanation of other options:

Meyerson phenomenon (Option B): Refers to an eczematous, pruritic reaction forming a halo around benign lesions, such as melanocytic nevi or other skin tumors, not associated with psoriasis or trauma-induced lesions.

Gottron's papule (Option C): These are violaceous, flat-topped papules found over bony prominences (e.g., knuckles) and are seen in dermatomyositis, not psoriasis.


Nikolsky's sign (Option D): Seen in blistering disorders like pemphigus vulgaris, this sign involves epidermal separation when lateral pressure is applied. It is not associated with psoriasis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with thickened, discolored toenails. Fungal culture confirms onychomycosis. The dermatologist prescribes a topical agent from the morpholine class in the form of a nail lacquer. Which of the following medications was most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
Amorolfine is a morpholine antifungal used topically as a nail lacquer for treating onychomycosis.

Amorolfine:

  • Class: Belongs to the morpholine class of antifungal agents.
  • Formulation: Available as a 5% nail lacquer used for the topical treatment of onychomycosis.
  • Mechanism of Action: Inhibits fungal ergosterol synthesis, targeting dermatophytes and yeasts.
  • Indications:
    • White superficial onychomycosis
    • Distal subungual onychomycosis (limited to distal nail of a few digits)
    • Used as monotherapy or as adjunctive therapy in more extensive disease
    • Also helpful for secondary prophylaxis in chronic/recurrent cases
  • Application Frequency: Once weekly application
  • Transungual Penetration:
    • Upon solvent evaporation, the drug concentration increases to 25%, enhancing nail plate diffusion
  • Effectiveness:
    • Achieves clinical response in approximately 50% of cases when used alone for mild distal subungual onychomycosis

Explanation of other options:

Oxiconazole (Option B): An imidazole antifungal, typically used in cream formulations for superficial fungal infections like tinea corporis. It is not used as a nail lacquer.

Ciclopirox olamine (Option C): An effective topical antifungal available as an 8% nail lacquer for onychomycosis, but it belongs to the hydroxypyridone class, not the morpholine class specified in the question.

Tioconazole (Option D): An imidazole antifungal, used mainly in topical treatments for cutaneous or vaginal candidiasis, but not commonly used as a nail lacquer.

Reference:

  1. https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/1532336/
  2. https://ijdvl.com/current-treatment-of-onychomycosis/#

questions.text: A newborn is admitted to the NICU shortly after birth due to thick, armor-like skin covering the entire body. On examination, the baby has ectropion, eclabium, contractures of the limbs, and deep fissures in the skin. The baby was born encased in a tight, shiny membrane, as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of thick hyperkeratotic skin plates, deep fissures, ectropion, eclabium, and respiratory distress in a newborn point towards a diagnosis of Harlequin ichthyosis.

Harlequin Ichthyosis:

  • Rare, life-threatening autosomal recessive skin disorder present at birth
  • Caused by mutations in the ABCA12 gene, impairing lipid transport essential for skin barrier function
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Defective lipid transport disrupts the epidermal barrier
    • Leads to massive hyperkeratosis, fluid loss, risk of infection, and impaired thermoregulation
  • Clinical Features:
    • Thick, plate-like ("armor-like") scales forming over the body
    • Ectropion (eyelids turned outward), eclabium (lips turned outward)
    • Contractures of digits, with underdeveloped fingers and toes
    • High risk for dehydration, secondary infections, and respiratory compromise
    • Delayed desquamation, with gradual improvement but requiring lifelong skin care
  • Diagnosis:
    • Primarily clinical, based on classic appearance at birth
    • Genetic testing confirms ABCA12 mutation
    • Skin biopsy is rarely needed; shows marked hyperkeratosis
  • Management:
    • NICU care with focus on hydration, temperature control, and infection prevention
    • Regular use of moisturizers and keratolytics (e.g., petrolatum, urea, lactic acid)
    • Oral retinoids (e.g., acitretin or isotretinoin) can reduce keratin buildup
    • Treat infections early with systemic antibiotics
    • Lifelong supportive skin care and dermatology follow-up

Explanation of other options:

Lamellar ichthyosis (Option B): Often presents at birth with a collodion membrane, followed by large, thick, dark scales over the body. Unlike harlequin ichthyosis, it lacks severe contractures, ectropion, eclabium, and deep fissures.

Bathing suit ichthyosis (Option C): A rare variant of lamellar ichthyosis where scaling predominantly affects the trunk and proximal limbs in a distribution resembling a bathing suit.

Ichthyosis vulgaris (Option D): A mild, common inherited skin condition with fine white or gray scaling, usually starting in early childhood and affecting extensor surfaces, not present at birth.

References:

  1. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK562318/

questions.text: A middle-aged male presents to the dermatology clinic with a two-week history of an mildly itchy rash on his flank, which has not responded to over-the-counter treatments. On examination, characteristic skin lesions are noted on his palms and the sole of one foot, as shown below. There are no oral lesions. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical image and distribution of target-shaped lesions with a dusky center and concentric zones particularly on the palms and soles are classic findings of erythema multiforme,

Erythema Multiforme:

  • Immune-mediated hypersensitivity reaction affecting skin and mucous membranes
  • Presents with targetoid skin lesions; triggered mainly by infections (HSV) or less commonly drugs
  • Classification
  • Cutaneous Features:
    • Target lesions with 3 concentric zones:
      • Peripheral erythema (± vesicle)
      • Middle pale edematous ring
      • Central dusky/necrotic area (± blister)
    • Symmetric distribution; favors acral areas (hands, feet, extensor limbs)
    • Lesions are usually <3cm and may be mildly pruritic, though less intensely itchy compared to urticaria.
    • Face and ears may be involved; trunk usually spared
  • Mucosal Involvement:
    • Common in EM major, especially oral mucosa
    • Lesions begin as blisters, evolve into erosions with pseudomembranes
    • Painful; may cause weight loss and dehydration due to poor oral intake
    • Crusting and fibrin-coated ulcers seen on lips, cheeks, palate, genitalia
  • Evaluation & Diagnosis:
    • Clinical diagnosis based on history and morphology
    • CBC: Leukocytosis, eosinophilia, mild anemia possible
    • PCR/Immunofluorescence: HSV or Mycoplasma detection
    • Chest X-ray: In suspected Mycoplasma pneumoniae EM
  • Management:
    • Supportive care: Pain relief, hydration, symptom control
    • Most cases resolve in 1-2 weeks
    • For recurrent HSV-associated EM: Consider long-term antivirals
    • Severe mucosal cases may need hospital care for nutrition and fluid support

Explanation of other options:

Urticaria (Option A) presents as transient, edematous, and intensely itchy wheals that come and go within 24 hours without leaving marks unlike the fixed target lesions seen in this case.

Viral exanthem (Option B) typically begin on the trunk and spread outward; they do not commonly involve palms and soles and lack the targetoid appearance.

Tinea manuum (Option D) usually presents as unilateral, dry, scaly, annular lesions with central clearing, not as multiple target-shaped lesions with dusky centers as seen here.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470259/

questions.text: A 52-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with gradual hair loss over the frontotemporal scalp. On examination, there is a band-like recession of the hairline with shiny, smooth skin and absence of follicular openings. The hair loss is permanent and progressive. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of frontotemporal recession with shiny skin and absent follicular ostia indicate scarring alopecia, characteristic of frontal fibrosing alopecia.

  • Frontal fibrosing alopecia (FFA) is classified as a scarring (cicatricial) alopecia.
  • It involves permanent hair loss due to fibrosis and irreversible destruction of hair follicles.
  • Unlike non-scarring types, follicular stem cells are lost, preventing hair regrowth.
  • In contrast, non-scarring alopecia maintains follicular structure, making the hair loss potentially reversible if the underlying trigger is removed.
  • Clinical hallmark: Smooth, shiny skin with absent follicular openings at the hairline.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents with the skin lesions shown below. He reports that the rash started with a single larger patch on the trunk, followed by multiple similar lesions distributed over the body. He denies any itching, pain, or systemic symptoms. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of asymptomatic, oval scaly lesions distributed along skin cleavage lines following a herald patch points toward a diagnosis of Pityriasis rosea.

Pityriasis Rosea (PR):

  • Acute, self-limiting papulosquamous disorder.
  • Common in adolescents and young adults (ages 15-30), but can also affect children and older adults.
  • Common sites: Thorax, back, abdomen, upper arms, neck.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Initial lesion: Herald patch (mother patch)
      • Slightly raised, oval, pink or salmon-colored, with fine central scaling.
      • Seen in 50-90% of cases.
      • Typically appears on the trunk, sometimes neck or proximal limbs.
    • Secondary eruption (after 1-2 weeks):
      • Symmetrical, ovoid macules/papules with collarette scaling.
      • Lesions follow Langer's lines, forming a "Christmas tree pattern on the back.
      • Scaling: Fine, central wrinkling resembling cigarette paper.
      • Typically asymptomatic or mildly pruritic, with severe itching in ~25% of cases.
    • Prodrome:
      • Fever, sore throat, arthralgia, or gastrointestinal upset.
  • Distribution Pattern:
    • Lesions are:
      • Bilateral, symmetric, and diffuse.
      • Elliptical/oval.
      • Long axis aligned with skin tension lines.
      • Show collarette scaling - edges of the scale attached peripherally and lifted centrally.
  • Course: Self-resolving in 6-8 weeks.
  • Management:
    • General care:
      • Emollients, soap substitutes, gentle sunlight exposure.
    • Symptomatic relief:
      • Antihistamines (for pruritus)
      • Topical corticosteroids

Explanation of other options:

Lichen planus (Option A): Typically presents as itchy, violaceous, flat-topped papules often affecting flexural surfaces, mucosa, and nails. The lesions here are asymptomatic and follow a truncal distribution, making LP unlikely.

Seborrheic dermatitis (Option C): Presents as greasy, erythematous plaques with yellowish scales, commonly on the scalp, face (especially nasolabial folds), and chest. The absence of itching and greasy texture here rule out this diagnosis.

Atopic dermatitis (Option D): Characteristically pruritic and associated with a history of atopy (asthma, allergic rhinitis), typically affecting flexures in adults. The patient's lesions are asymptomatic and located on the trunk, which is not typical.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK448091/

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with intensely itchy eczematous plaques over her abdomen and limbs. She reports the rash has worsened over the last few weeks. A skin biopsy reveals a subepidermal blister, and direct immunofluorescence demonstrates linear deposition of IgG and C3 along the basement membrane zone. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of pruritic eczematous plaques, subepidermal cleft on biopsy, and linear IgG and C3 deposition on immunofluorescence strongly indicate bullous pemphigoid.

Bullous Pemphigoid:

  • Common subepidermal autoimmune blistering disorder
  • Predominantly affects the elderly
  • Autoantibodies are directed against hemidesmosomal proteins:
    • BP230 (BPAG1)
    • BP180 (BPAG2)
  • Clinical Stages:
    1. Prodromal (non-bullous) phase:
      • Presents with itchy, eczematous or urticarial plaques
    2. Bullous phase:
      • Tense vesicles and bullae on erythematous or normal skin
      • Intense pruritus
      • Blisters may rupture to form hemorrhagic or yellow crusts
      • Healing without scarring
      • Oral lesions may occasionally occur
  • Diagnostic Features:
    • Histopathology:
      • Subepidermal split with eosinophil-rich inflammatory infiltrate
    • Direct Immunofluorescence (DIF):
      • Linear IgG and C3 deposition along the dermoepidermal junction
    • Antibody involved: IgG
  • Clinical Signs:
    • Nikolsky sign: Negative
    • Bulla spread sign: Positive
  • Treatment:
    • First-line: Topical and systemic corticosteroids
    • Immunosuppressive agents may be added in severe/refractory cases

Explanation of other options:

Pemphigus vulgaris (Option A): This shows intraepidermal blistering due to acantholysis and presents with intercellular IgG deposits on immunofluorescence ("fishnet pattern"), not the linear basement membrane staining seen here.

Dermatitis herpetiformis (Option C): Characterized by grouped vesicles on extensor surfaces and associated with celiac disease, it shows granular IgA deposits in the dermal papillae, not linear IgG and C3.

Pemphigus foliaceus (Option D): This is a superficial blistering disorder affecting the upper epidermis; immunofluorescence shows intercellular IgG without subepidermal cleft or linear basement membrane staining.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with fever, joint pain, and difficulty getting up from the floor. On examination, reddish, scaly plaques are observed over the knuckles, as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of violaceous, scaly papules over the extensor surfaces of the MCP and PIP joints is characteristic of Gottron's papules, a hallmark of juvenile dermatomyositis, especially in a child with fever and muscle weakness.

Juvenile Dermatomyositis (JDM):

  • A rare autoimmune inflammatory myopathy primarily affecting children
  • Involves both skin and proximal muscles
  • Clinical Features:
    • Muscle Weakness:
      • Predominantly proximal (e.g., difficulty in climbing stairs, rising from a chair, or lifting arms to comb hair)
    • Characteristic Skin Findings:
      • Gottron's papules: Red or violaceous, scaly plaques over knuckles, elbows, knees

      • Heliotrope rash: Purple discoloration with or without swelling of upper eyelids

    • Systemic Symptoms:
      • May include fever, fatigue, malaise, and arthralgia or arthritis
  • Investigations:
    • Muscle Enzymes:
      • Elevated creatine kinase (CK), aldolase, LDH, AST/ALT
    • Autoantibodies:
      • May include anti-Jo-1 or other myositis-specific antibodies
    • Electromyography (EMG):
      • Shows myopathic changes
    • Muscle biopsy:
      • Confirms diagnosis; shows inflammation, fiber necrosis, and perifascicular atrophy
  • Treatment Approach:
    • First-line:
      • Systemic corticosteroids
    • Steroid-sparing agents:
      • Methotrexate, azathioprine
    • For refractory/severe cases:
      • IVIG (intravenous immunoglobulin)
    • Supportive care:
      • Physiotherapy and monitoring for complications (e.g., calcinosis, vasculopathy)

Explanation of other options:

Rheumatoid nodules - Juvenile rheumatoid arthritis (Option B): Rheumatoid nodules are firm, non-tender subcutaneous swellings typically over extensor surfaces like the elbows and are not scaly or erythematous. They lack the violaceous discoloration and distribution over knuckles seen with Gottron's papules.


Sclerodactyly - Systemic sclerosis (Option C): Sclerodactyly presents with tight, thickened, shiny skin over the fingers and is often associated with Raynaud's phenomenon. It does not produce scaly plaques or papules on the knuckles.


Mechanic's hand - Systemic lupus erythematosus (Option D): Mechanic's hands show hyperkeratotic, fissured skin on palms and fingers, associated with antisynthetase syndrome, not SLE. Additionally, the knuckle involvement seen here is more typical of Gottron's papules.

questions.text: A 12-week pregnant woman undergoing multidrug therapy (MDT) for multibacillary leprosy presents with fever, painful erythematous nodules on her limbs, and general malaise. What is the most appropriate next step in her management?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario suggests erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL), a type 2 lepra reaction, which is a type III hypersensitivity response seen in multibacillary leprosy. The recommended treatment during pregnancy is to continue MDT and add oral corticosteroids.

Type 2 Lepra Reaction (Erythema Nodosum Leprosum - ENL):

  • Hypersensitivity Type: Immune complex-mediated (Type III hypersensitivity).
  • Cause: Reaction to antigens from Mycobacterium leprae.
  • Pathology: Neutrophilic vasculitis due to deposition of immune complexes.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Cutaneous: Painful, erythematous nodules (may ulcerate).
    • Systemic: Fever, malaise, asthenia.
    • Other Organ Involvement:
      • Nerves: Neuritis
      • Joints: Arthritis, synovitis
      • Eyes: Iridocyclitis
      • Testes: Epididymo-orchitis
      • Liver & Kidneys: Hepatitis, glomerulonephritis
      • Lymphatics: Lymphadenopathy
  • Management:
    • Continue MDT: Essential to prevent relapse, even during reaction.
    • First-line treatment: Oral corticosteroids (e.g., prednisolone) - safe in pregnancy.
    • Supportive care: Analgesics, wound care for ulcerated lesions.
    • Drugs to Avoid in Pregnancy: Thalidomide (Option C) - Teratogenic, associated with severe congenital anomalies like phocomelia.

Explanation of other options:

Stop MDT and start oral steroids (Option A): Stopping MDT during a type 2 lepra reaction is not recommended, as it may worsen the underlying leprosy and increase the risk of relapse. MDT should be continued, with steroids added to control the immune-mediated inflammation.

Antibiotics (Option B): ENL is an immune-mediated reaction, not a bacterial infection. Antibiotics are ineffective for ENL and do not address the underlying hypersensitivity.

Reference:

  1. https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC8749206/

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with thickening and yellowish discoloration of her great toenail, along with subungual debris and surface irregularity, as shown in the image. Laboratory tests confirm a fungal infection. Which of the following is the most appropriate topical treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of nail discoloration with subungual hyperkeratosis and fungal examination confirming dermatophyte infection point toward a diagnosis of distal lateral subungual onychomycosis. Tavaborole is the preferred topical antifungal in mild to moderate cases of distal subungual onychomycosis.


Explanation of other options:

Itraconazole (Option A): An oral antifungal effective for moderate to severe onychomycosis, but inappropriate for this question as it is not a topical agent.

Griseofulvin (Option C) is an oral antifungal used mainly for tinea infections of the skin and scalp; it has poor efficacy in toenail onychomycosis.

Caspofungin (Option D) is an intravenous echinocandin used for invasive systemic fungal infections (e.g., candidemia), and it is not indicated or effective for nail infections like onychomycosis.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK441853/#

questions.text:
A patient presents with a chronic, asymptomatic lesion over the neck. There are no associated systemic symptoms. Based on the clinical presentation and the image shown below, which of the following investigations would be most helpful?

1. KOH preparation
2. Skin biopsy
3. Chest X-ray (TB workup)
4. HIV testing
questions.solution:
The clinical features of a chronic, asymptomatic skin lesion, along with the image showing a group of erythematous violaceous annular plaques with central scarring and atrophy with active margins, point towards the diagnosis of Lupus vulgaris, a chronic form of cutaneous tuberculosis. Skin biopsy confirms the diagnosis by revealing granulomatous inflammation with caseation, while a chest X-ray helps assess for any underlying pulmonary tuberculosis, which may act as a primary focus of infection.

Lupus Vulgaris:

  • A chronic, slowly progressive paucibacillary form of cutaneous tuberculosis.
  • Epidemiology:
    • Most common type of cutaneous TB in adults.
    • More frequently observed in females.
  • Etiology:
    • Caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis or Mycobacterium bovis.
  • Pathogenesis:
    • Occurs in individuals previously sensitized to tuberculosis.
    • Spread may be endogenous (via blood or lymph from a primary focus) or exogenous (direct inoculation).
    • Strong cell-mediated immune response leads to granuloma formation.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Appears as one or multiple red to violaceous annular plaques with:
      • Central scarring and atrophy
      • Active elevated margins
    • On diascopy, nodules may show apple jelly color (a classical sign).
    • Commonly affects the face, upper limbs, and buttocks.
    • Lesions may gradually enlarge or recur in areas of previous scarring.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Skin biopsy shows granulomatous inflammation ± caseation necrosis.
    • Chest X-ray to evaluate for underlying pulmonary TB.
  • Treatment:
    • Anti-tubercular therapy (ATT) is the mainstay of treatment.
    • Early treatment helps prevent scarring and complications.
  • Complications:
    • Disfiguring scarring
    • Rarely, transformation to squamous cell carcinoma

Explanation of other options:

KOH preparation (Option 1): Used to identify fungal elements in superficial infections like tinea; not useful for diagnosing tuberculosis.

HIV testing (Option 4): Though important in immunocompromised states, this patient has no systemic symptoms or opportunistic infections to warrant immediate HIV screening for diagnosis.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding skin histology and embryological origin are correct?
1. Epidermis has the ability to regenerate from adnexal structures such as hair follicles and sebaceous glands
2. Stratum corneum is the outermost layer containing living cells
3. The epidermis is derived from ectodermal origin
4. Dermis and subcutaneous tissue are derived from the endoderm
questions.solution:
The correct statements are statements 1 and 3.

Epidermis:

  • Derived from surface ectoderm. (Statement 3)
  • Has regenerative potential from epidermal appendages such as: (Statement 1)
    • Hair follicles
    • Sebaceous glands
    • Sweat glands
  • These structures contain keratinocyte stem cells that help restore the epidermis after injury or grafting.
  • Layers of Epidermis (from outermost to innermost):
    1. Stratum corneum: Composed of dead, flat, anucleate keratinized cells that provide a tough, protective outer barrier. (Statement 2)
    2. Stratum lucidum: A thin, translucent layer of dead keratinocytes found only in thick, hairless skin.
    3. Stratum granulosum: Contains keratinocytes with keratohyalin granules that help form a waterproof barrier.
    4. Stratum spinosum: Known as the "prickle cell layer" due to desmosomal connections between keratinocytes.
    5. Stratum basale: The deepest layer; consists of mitotically active basal cells that regenerate the epidermis.

Embryological Origin of the Skin:

  • Surface Ectoderm Derivatives:
    • Develops into:
      • Epidermis
      • Hair
      • Sweat and sebaceous glands
      • Nails
    • Mesodermal Derivatives: (Statement 4)
      • Dermis and hypodermis (subcutaneous tissue)

questions.text: A male neonate, born to non-consanguineous parents, presents with fluid-filled blisters over areas of friction. The parents report that a previous sibling had similar skin issues and passed away at 2 weeks of age. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of blistering with a family history of early neonatal death suggests a genetic blistering disorder like epidermolysis bullosa.

Epidermolysis Bullosa (EB):

  • A group of inherited disorders marked by skin and mucous membrane blistering after minor trauma or friction.
  • Often presents in infancy or early childhood; a family history may support diagnosis.
  • Genetic Basis:
    • Results from mutations in genes responsible for structural proteins of the skin (e.g., keratins, laminins, collagens).
    • Leads to defective dermo-epidermal adhesion, making the skin extremely fragile.
  • Types of EB:
    1. EB Simplex - Blistering occurs within the epidermis (most common, milder form).
    2. Junctional EB - Blisters form at the level of the lamina lucida within the basement membrane zone.
    3. Dystrophic EB - Involves deeper layers; scarring and fusion of digits ("mitten-hand deformity") may occur.
    4. Kindler Syndrome - A mixed-level blistering disorder with photosensitivity and poikiloderma.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Blisters and erosions form easily after minimal friction or trauma.
    • Mucosal surfaces (oral cavity, esophagus, conjunctiva, genitals) are often involved.
    • Recurrent infections, scarring, and nutritional deficiencies may develop.
    • Severe subtypes may lead to growth retardation, anemia, and joint deformities.
  • Diagnostic Approach:
    • Skin biopsy with immunofluorescence mapping: Determines the level of skin separation and affected protein.
    • Genetic testing: Identifies the specific gene mutation involved.
    • Electron microscopy: Offers detailed visualization of structural abnormalities at the skin junction.

Explanation of other options:

Chronic bullous disorder of childhood (Option B): This is an acquired, autoimmune blistering condition typically seen in children aged 2-5 years, not in neonates. It presents with annular blisters and "string of pearls" appearance, unlike the inherited neonatal blistering in this case.

Congenital syphilis (Option C): While congenital syphilis can cause vesiculobullous lesions, it usually presents with other systemic features like hepatosplenomegaly, snuffles, or skeletal abnormalities, and can be confirmed with serologic tests.

Neonatal pemphigus (Option D): This autoimmune condition results from transplacental transfer of maternal antibodies and is usually benign, self-limited, and lacks a family history of severe early neonatal death as seen in inherited disorders like EB.

questions.text: A school-aged child presents to the dermatology outpatient department with patterned lesions over the hand, following recent henna application. Her mother reports that the child frequently scratches her hand while studying. Based on the history and the clinical pattern seen in the image, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presentation of well-demarcated, bizarrely shaped lesions, especially with a history of habitual scratching, suggests Dermatitis artefacta.

Dermatitis Artefacta:

  • A self-inflicted skin condition, either consciously or subconsciously, often linked to underlying psychological disturbances.
  • Classified as a psychiatric disorder rather than a primary dermatologic disease.
  • Lesion Characteristics:
    • Lesions are atypical in shape and distribution.
    • May have bizarre or geometric patterns.
    • Do not correspond to known dermatological conditions.
  • Behavioral Clues:
    • The patient may deny causing the lesions.
    • Lesions often appear in accessible areas (e.g., front of body, dominant hand side).
    • Abrupt onset with lack of typical disease progression.
  • Diagnosis: Clinical suspicion arises from an inconsistent history and unusual lesion morphology; the diagnosis is often made after excluding other potential causes.
  • Management:
    • Requires a multidisciplinary team, including dermatologists and mental health professionals.
    • Focuses on psychological evaluation, behavioral therapy, and supportive care.
    • Building trust and a non-confrontational approach is key to effective management.

Explanation of other options:

Contact dermatitis due to henna (Option A): Allergic reactions typically present with diffuse erythema, vesicles, or itching, not patterned or deliberate-appearing lesions.

Polymorphous light eruption (Option C) (PMLE) occurs due to UV exposure, especially on sun-exposed areas, and does not correlate with henna or scratching habits.

Vitiligo (Option D): Presents as well-defined depigmented macules, not erythematous or excoriated lesions, and is not self-inflicted.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK430936/

questions.text: A child presents with brittle, fragile hair that easily breaks. Based on the findings shown in the image, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of brittle hair with tiger-tail banding under polarized light microscopy, as shown in the image, strongly suggests a diagnosis of Trichothiodystrophy.

Trichothiodystrophy (TTD):

  • A rare inherited condition that primarily affects the structural integrity of hair and may involve multiple systems.
  • Characteristic Microscopic Feature: Under polarized light, hair shafts exhibit alternating light and dark bands known as "tiger tail banding", which is diagnostic of TTD.
  • Primary Hair Abnormality: Hair is notably brittle and prone to breakage, often the first visible sign in affected individuals.
  • Common Associated Findings:
    • Variable hair pigmentation
    • Dry, scaly skin
    • Fragile nails
    • Photosensitivity
    • Eye abnormalities
  • Neurological and Developmental Involvement: Some individuals may present with intellectual disabilities, developmental delays, and other systemic symptoms.

Explanation of other options:

Trichorrhexis nodosa(Option A): This condition shows fractures and nodular thickening of the hair shaft due to mechanical or chemical damage, but does not exhibit tiger tail banding under polarized light.

Trichorexisinvaginata (Option B): Also known as "bamboo hair," it features hair shafts with telescoping invaginations and is classically associated with Netherton syndrome, not trichothiodystrophy.

Monilethrix(Option D): Presents with beaded or necklace-like hair shafts due to regular constrictions, but lacks the alternating dark and light bands seen under polarized light in trichothiodystrophy.

Reference:

https://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0190962204024880

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK6285/

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with chronic itchy, erythematous patches on her hands and wrists that worsen after wearing metal bangles. Her symptoms are suggestive of a delayed hypersensitivity reaction triggered by external substances. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic test?
questions.solution:
The patch test helps identify allergens causing allergic contact dermatitis, a Type IV (delayed) hypersensitivity reaction. It involves applying suspected allergens on the skin and evaluating reactions after 48-72 hours.


Explanation of other options:

Eosin-5'-maleimide binding test (Option C): This is used to diagnose hereditary spherocytosis, a red blood cell membrane disorder. It has no relevance to dermatological or allergic conditions.

Nitroblue tetrazolium (NBT) test (Option D) evaluates neutrophil function and is used to diagnose chronic granulomatous disease. It is unrelated to skin allergy or hypersensitivity testing.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK537020/

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a history of recurrent genital warts visits the outpatient clinic. She is currently experiencing an active outbreak. Her husband has never shown symptoms of the condition. What is the most appropriate advice to prevent transmission to her partner?
questions.solution:
Genital warts are caused by human papillomavirus (HPV) and are most infectious when visible lesions are present. The safest and most effective method to prevent transmission is to avoid sexual contact during active outbreaks, as the virus is shed from lesions during this time.

Management of Genital Warts:

  • Individual Treatment:
    1. Topical Therapies:
      • Imiquimod cream: Stimulates local immune response to help eliminate the wart.
      • Trichloroacetic acid (TCA) or Bichloroacetic acid (BCA): Applied directly to destroy wart tissue.
    2. Surgical Procedures:
      • Cryotherapy: Freezing warts with liquid nitrogen.
      • Electrocautery: Burning the lesion using an electric current.
      • Surgical excision: Physically cutting out the wart, typically reserved for larger lesions.
  • Partner Management:
    • Inform sexual partner(s): They should be evaluated and treated if needed.
    • Sexual activity precautions: Avoid intercourse during active lesions to reduce the risk of transmission.

Explanation of other options:

Continuous prophylaxis for the patient (Option A): Routine long-term prophylaxis is not standard practice for genital warts. Management focuses on treating active lesions and monitoring for recurrence.

Prophylactic antivirals for the husband (Option B): No antivirals prevent HPV transmission. HPV vaccines are preventive but not indicated for active infections.

Antivirals during active lesions (Option C): Although topical or procedural treatments can help reduce the appearance of genital warts, they do not eliminate the virus. Therefore, relying solely on treatment during active outbreaks does not fully prevent the risk of HPV transmission.

questions.text: A young woman presents to the dermatology OPD with facial skin complaints. Based on the image provided, which of the following topical agents is not appropriate for treating her condition?
questions.solution:
Topical fluocinolone is a corticosteroid that is not used for acne management. Instead of improving acne, it can worsen the condition by promoting follicular occlusion, sebum production, and even steroid-induced acne.

Acne Vulgaris:

  • A chronic inflammatory skin disorder involving the pilosebaceous units.
  • Common during adolescence, but can persist or occur in adults.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Increased sebum production: Stimulated by androgens.
    • Follicular hyperkeratinization: Leads to comedone (plug) formation.
    • Bacterial proliferation: Particularly Cutibacterium acnes in blocked follicles.
    • Inflammation: Triggers the development of papules, pustules, and nodules.

Explanation of other options:

Topical benzoyl peroxide (Option A): Benzoyl peroxide is a first-line acne treatment. It has antibacterial, anti-inflammatory properties and helps prevent antibiotic resistance when used in combination.

Topical tazarotene (Option C): Tazarotene is a topical retinoid that promotes normal keratinocyte turnover, reduces comedone formation, and is widely used in acne therapy.

Topical antibiotics (Option D): Topical antibiotics like clindamycin or erythromycin help reduce Cutibacterium acnes and inflammation. They're often prescribed alongside benzoyl peroxide to minimize resistance.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male from Bihar presents to the dermatology OPD with hypopigmented lesions over his back as shown below. The lesions are not associated with any sensory loss, and no thickened peripheral nerves are noted. He recalls having prolonged fever during his childhood. Based on this presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The absence of sensory loss and nerve thickening, presence of hypopigmented macules, history of prolonged fever in childhood, and residence in an endemic area like Bihar point toward Post Kala-azar Dermal Leishmaniasis (PKDL).


Post Kala-Azar Dermal Leishmaniasis (PKDL):

  • Skin manifestation that appears after recovery from visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar), caused by Leishmania donovani.
  • It typically emerges months to years following successful treatment of visceral leishmaniasis.
  • Epidemiology:
    • Commonly reported in endemic regions such as India (notably Bihar, West Bengal, and Uttar Pradesh), Nepal, and Sudan.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Skin lesions may include:
      • Hypopigmented macules
      • Erythematous papules
      • Nodules
      • Distribution usually involves the face, trunk, and limbs.
    • Sensation is preserved, and there is no thickening of peripheral nerves, features that help differentiate PKDL from leprosy.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Microscopy: Slit-skin smear or biopsy revealing Leishmania donovani (LD) bodies.
    • Molecular/Serologic tests: PCR or rK39 serological test may support the diagnosis.
  • Treatment:
    • Miltefosine (oral) is the first-line therapy, typically administered for 12 weeks.
    • Other options:
      • Liposomal amphotericin B
      • Paromomycin

Explanation of other options:

Tuberculoid leprosy (Option A): Typically presents with hypopigmented anesthetic patches and thickened peripheral nerves, which are absent in this case.

Lepromatous leprosy (Option B): Manifests as multiple ill-defined lesions, often with bilateral symmetric involvement, nerve thickening, and sensation loss.

Mycosis fungoides (Option C): A cutaneous T-cell lymphoma presenting with erythematous, scaly plaques, not hypopigmented macules; no link to prior febrile illness or endemic exposure.

Reference:

Post Kala-Azar Dermal Leishmaniasis: Clinical Features and Differential Diagnosis - PMC

questions.text: A child presents with hair loss and an itchy, inflamed patch on the scalp, as shown in the image below. What is the most appropriate initial investigation?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of scalp itching and hair loss, along with the image showing a scaly, inflamed, well-demarcated lesion, points toward a diagnosis of Tinea capitis. The most appropriate initial investigation in this case is a KOH mount, which helps visualize fungal hyphae in affected hair shafts or skin scales.


Tinea Capitis:

  • Etiology:
    • Caused by dermatophytes: Trichophyton and Microsporum species.
    • More common in children, especially in hot and humid climates.
  • Clinical Types:
    • Non-inflammatory:
      • Presents as scaly patches with black dots or broken hairs.
    • Inflammatory (Kerion):
      • Painful, boggy swelling with pustules and crusting (may resemble an abscess).
  • Diagnosis:
    • KOH mount: Reveals fungal elements in hair or skin scrapings.
    • Fungal culture: Confirms species.
    • Wood’s lamp: Shows green fluorescence in Microsporum infections.
  • Treatment:
    • Oral antifungals: Griseofulvin or Terbinafine for 6-8 weeks (essential for cure).
    • Adjunct shampoos: Ketoconazole or selenium sulfide to reduce transmission.
    • Kerion cases: May require systemic corticosteroids to control inflammation.

Explanation of other options:

Slit Skin Smear (Option B): Used primarily to diagnose leprosy by detecting acid-fast bacilli in skin lesions; it has no role in diagnosing fungal scalp infections like tinea capitis.

Gram Stain (Option C): Used to detect bacterial organisms in skin infections; it cannot identify dermatophyte fungi responsible for tinea capitis.

Skin Biopsy (Option D): A more invasive test reserved for unclear or atypical cases; it is not the first-line investigation in straightforward cases of suspected fungal scalp infection.

questions.text: A child is brought to the clinic with multiple tiny, smooth papules seen over the forearm, as shown in the image below. Further history reveals similar asymptomatic lesions on the shaft of the penis. There is no itching or discomfort reported. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The child has asymptomatic, dome-shaped, shiny papules on both the forearm and genital area, which is a classical presentation of Lichen nitidus.


Lichen Nitidus:

  • Rare chronic inflammatory skin condition.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Tiny, dome-shaped, shiny papules.
    • Typically asymptomatic.
    • Lesions are uniform in size and may be skin-colored or hypopigmented.
  • Common Locations:
    • Forearms
    • Dorsum of the hands
    • Trunk
    • Shaft of the penis (considered characteristic)
  • Possible Associations:
    • Atopic dermatitis
    • Crohn's disease
    • Lichen planus
  • Diagnosis:
    • Mainly clinical.
    • Skin biopsy (if performed) shows a distinctive "claw clutching a ball" lymphocytic pattern.

  • Treatment:
    • Often not needed if no symptoms.
    • Symptomatic cases may respond to topical corticosteroids, calcineurin inhibitors, or emollients.
  • Prognosis:
    • Typically self-resolving over time but may persist for extended periods.

Explanation of other options:

Lichen Planus (Option A): Typically presents as pruritic, violaceous, flat-topped papules often with Wickham’s striae. It commonly affects flexor wrists, oral mucosa, and lower legs, and is usually itchy, unlike the asymptomatic lesions seen here.


Scrofuloderma (Option C): This is a cutaneous tuberculosis presenting as cold abscesses or ulcerated sinuses overlying lymph nodes or bones, not smooth, tiny, discrete papules.


Scabies (Option D): Characterized by intense itching, especially at night, with burrows and papulovesicular lesions in finger webs, wrists, and genitalia; the absence of pruritus and burrows makes this diagnosis unlikely.


Reference: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31869173/

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic patient presents with a persistent lesion on the nose that bleeds on touch, as seen in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical feature of a slow-growing lesion, along with the image showing a pearly nodule with telangiectasia on the nose that bleeds on touch, points towards a diagnosis of basal cell carcinoma.


Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC):

  • Also Known As: Rodent ulcer.
  • The commonest type of skin cancer.
  • Slow-growing and locally destructive.
  • Rarely metastasizes.
  • Origin:
    • Arises from pluripotent basal cells in the epidermis or hair follicle structures.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Initial Presentation:
      • Appears as a small, scaly or pearly papule or plaque.
    • Progression:
      • Gradual peripheral spread.
      • Evolves into nodulo-ulcerative lesions with:
        • Rolled or thread-like edges
        • Surface telangiectasia
        • Tendency to bleed on minor trauma
  • Common Sites:
    • Face (especially around the eyes and nose)
  • Histopathological Features:
    • Nests of basaloid cells resembling stratum basale.
    • Peripheral palisading of tumor cells.
    • Cells extend downward into the dermis.
    • Presence of organized stromal tissue surrounding the tumor islands.
  • Management:
    • Medical Therapies:
      • Topical: Imiquimod, 5-Fluorouracil (5-FU)
      • Intralesional: Interferon alpha-2b
      • Targeted: Vismodegib (hedgehog pathway inhibitor)
    • Surgical Treatment:
      • Standard excision or Mohs micrographic surgery
        • Mohs is preferred for high-risk or recurrent lesions, particularly on the face.

Explanation of other options:

Squamous cell carcinoma (Option A) often presents as a hard, hyperkeratotic lesion with crusting or scaling, typically on sun-exposed areas, but it lacks the classic pearly borders and telangiectasia seen in basal cell carcinoma. Bleeding may occur, but the lesion is more indurated and less translucent.


Melanoma (Option C) usually shows asymmetric pigmentation, irregular borders, and color variation (ABCDE criteria), which are not features of the lesion described here. It rarely presents as a pearly nodule that bleeds on touch.


Discoid lupus erythematosus (Option D) presents as erythematous, scaly, and atrophic plaques, primarily without ulceration or spontaneous bleeding. The chronic, non-ulcerative nature and lack of rolled borders differentiate it from basal cell carcinoma.

questions.text: A 13-year-old obese child presents to the dermatology clinic with dark, thickened skin over the neck and axilla, as shown in the image below. The lesions are asymptomatic but have gradually progressed over the past few months. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of an obese child with velvety, hyperpigmented thickening of the axilla and neck, as shown in the image, is indicative of acanthosis nigricans.


Acanthosis Nigricans:

  • Pathogenesis:
  • Results from epidermal hyperkeratosis without an increase in melanin or melanocyte count.
  • Driven by elevated insulin or IGF-1 (insulin-like growth factor 1) levels.
  • Types:
    1. Benign Form:
      • Commonly associated with obesity, insulin resistance, type 2 diabetes, PCOS, hypothyroidism, and acromegaly.
    2. Malignant Form:
      • Sudden onset and widespread involvement.
      • Acts as a paraneoplastic sign, often linked to intra-abdominal malignancies, especially gastric adenocarcinoma.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Velvety, hyperpigmented plaques.
    • Most commonly affects intertriginous areas: Neck, axillae, groin, and inner thighs.
    • Lesions are typically bilateral and symmetrical.
    • May be accompanied by skin tags (acrochordons) in the same regions.
    • Serves as a cutaneous indicator of underlying metabolic disorders.
  • Management:
    • Primary focus: Treat the underlying condition (e.g., obesity, diabetes, PCOS).
    • Lifestyle changes: Weight reduction, dietary modifications, and improved insulin sensitivity.
    • Topical therapies: Keratolytics (e.g., salicylic acid), topical retinoids, or urea-based creams for cosmetic improvement.

Explanation of other options:

Tinea Versicolor (Option B): Caused by Malassezia species, it presents as scaly hypo- or hyperpigmented macules, not as velvety thickening, and typically affects the chest, back, or shoulders, not flexural areas.


Seborrheic Keratosis (Option C): Common in older adults, it appears as well-demarcated, waxy, or "stuck-on" plaques, not as diffuse, velvety hyperpigmentation in adolescents.


Atopic Dermatitis (Option D): Typically presents as itchy, inflamed, and dry lesions in flexural areas, not with asymptomatic, velvety hyperpigmented patches seen in acanthosis nigricans.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with a 3-year history of recurrent fluid-filled blisters and painful oral erosions. A skin biopsy was performed, and the histopathological image is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The combination of flaccid blisters, oral mucosal involvement, and histology showing suprabasal clefting with acantholysis supports the diagnosis of pemphigus vulgaris.

Pemphigus Vulgaris:

  • Autoimmune blistering disorder targeting skin and mucous membranes.
  • Pathogenesis: Caused by IgG autoantibodies directed against desmoglein 3 (and sometimes desmoglein 1), components of desmosomes responsible for keratinocyte adhesion.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Presents with flaccid, easily ruptured bullae on normal or erythematous skin.
    • Painful erosions result once blisters rupture.
    • Mucosal involvement (especially oral) is a hallmark feature and often precedes skin lesions.
    • Lesions heal slowly and may become secondarily infected.

  • Histopathological Findings:
    • Suprabasal acantholysis: Keratinocytes lose cohesion just above the basal layer.
    • Appearance of "row of tombstones": Basal cells remain attached to the basement membrane while upper layers are detached.
    • Acantholytic cells (rounded, free-floating keratinocytes) are visible within the blister cavity.

Explanation of other options:

Dermatitis herpetiformis (Option B): Presents with intensely pruritic, grouped vesicles on extensor surfaces; histopathology shows subepidermal blisters with neutrophilic infiltrate, and direct immunofluorescence confirms granular IgA deposits in dermal papillae, not intraepidermal acantholysis.


Bullous pemphigoid (Option C): Causes tense blisters and rarely involves the oral mucosa; histology shows subepidermal blisters and immunofluorescence reveals linear IgG and C3 along the basement membrane.


Linear IgA disease (Option D): A subepidermal blistering disorder with linear deposition of IgA along the dermoepidermal junction; typically lacks suprabasal acantholysis and classic mucosal involvement seen in pemphigus vulgaris.


Reference: Pathogenesis, clinical manifestations, and diagnosis of pemphigus - UpToDate

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with a painful swelling over his scalp that has persisted for approximately 3 months. On examination, the swelling is soft, boggy, and shows pus discharge with areas of hair loss. The child mentions that there is a pet dog at home. Based on the clinical image and history, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a soft, boggy, pus-discharging scalp swelling with hair loss in a child, especially with a history of pet exposure, strongly points toward Kerion.


Explanation of other options:

Furuncle (Option A) is a painful, localized bacterial abscess involving a hair follicle, typically caused by Staphylococcus aureus. It presents as a tender, erythematous nodule, not a boggy swelling with pus discharge and hair loss.


Epidermoid cyst (Option B) is a benign, firm, subcutaneous nodule filled with keratin, not associated with pus discharge, hair loss, or boggy swelling.


Folliculitis (Option D) involves superficial bacterial or fungal infection of hair follicles, presenting as small pustules or papules around hairs, not a large, boggy, discharging lesion.

questions.text:
A child presents with a history of night blindness and the following skin findings:

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The combination of night blindness and follicular hyperkeratotic papules strongly suggests vitamin A deficiency, characteristic of phrynoderma.

Phrynoderma:



Explanation of other options:

Keratosis pilaris (Option B): Though it presents with similar follicular papules, it is a benign hereditary condition and not associated with night blindness or vitamin A deficiency.


Darier disease (Option C): This genetic disorder presents with greasy, crusted papules in seborrheic areas and does not occur in the context of vitamin A deficiency or visual symptoms.


Follicular atopic dermatitis (Option D): Pruritic, erythematous papules around hair follicles in atopic dermatitis, not associated with night blindness or nutritional deficiencies.


Reference: https://www.mja.com.au/journal/2024/221/2/phrynoderma-under-recognised-condition-reflecting-nutritional-deficiency

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with multiple anogenital warts as shown below. A biopsy of these lesions reveals squamous atypia. Which of the following human papillomavirus (HPV) types is considered high-risk?
questions.solution:
HPV 18 is considered high-risk because it is associated with anogenital warts that show squamous atypia and has a strong link to malignant transformation.


Explanation of other options:

HPV 2 (Option A): Low-risk; typically causes common (non-genital) warts, not linked to malignancy.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old patient presents with progressive nail changes over the past few months. There is no history of trauma or systemic illness. On examination, the nails appear discolored with surface irregularities and debris accumulation beneath the nail plate, as shown below:

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image displays features such as irregular pitting and subungual hyperkeratosis, which are hallmark nail findings in psoriasis.

Nail Psoriasis:

  • Nail psoriasis may present as:
    • The first sign of cutaneous psoriasis
    • A sequela (consequence) of skin psoriasis
    • A concurrent manifestation of skin psoriasis
  • Caused by psoriatic involvement of the nail bed or nail matrix
  • Nail changes can predict current or future psoriatic arthritis, particularly in the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints
  • Common Clinical Findings in Nail Psoriasis:
    1. Pitting: Studded depressions in the nail plate
    2. Subungual hyperkeratosis: White keratin debris overlying the nail bed
    3. Onycholysis: Distal separation of the nail plate from the nail bed
    4. Oil-drop discoloration: Pink macule or patch on the proximal nail, or red discoloration of the lunula
    5. Nail crumbling: Disintegration of the distal nail
    6. Leukonychia: White lines on the nail plate
    7. Splinter hemorrhages: Red, linear streaks under the nail

Explanation of other options:

Lichen planus (Option A): Typically causes pterygium formation, nail thinning, and longitudinal ridging, not subungual hyperkeratosis.


Atopic dermatitis (Option C): May cause brittle nails with longitudinal ridges due to chronic rubbing/scratching, but lacks pitting or subungual hyperkeratosis.


Alopecia areata (Option D): Shows regular, geometric pitting and may present with trachyonychia (rough, sandpaper-like nails).


Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK559260/

questions.text: A 30-year-old individual presents with moist, flat lesions around the perianal region. On examination, there are widespread asymptomatic macules over the chest and distinct patchy hair loss localized to the scalp, as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of broad-based moist papules in the anogenital region (likely condyloma lata), diffuse macular rash, and patchy non-scarring hair loss resembling a "moth-eaten" appearance is characteristic of secondary syphilis.

Characteristic Skin Lesions in Secondary Syphilis:

  • General Skin Lesion Features:
    • Lesions are typically bilaterally symmetrical and polymorphic.
    • Usually non-vesicular; vesicles and bullae are not observed in secondary syphilis.
  • Macular (Roseola) Rash:
    • Early presentation: pink to rose-colored macules on the trunk.
    • These may evolve into papules over time.
  • Papular Syphilide:
    • Most common type in secondary syphilis.
    • Found on moist, intertriginous areas such as the perianal and genital regions.
    • Papules can become eroded or macerated from friction.
  • Condyloma Lata:
    • Appears as broad-based, flat-topped, moist papules.
    • Often found in warm, moist folds (e.g., anogenital, inframammary regions).
    • Highly infectious.
  • Corona Veneris:
    • Papules were distributed along the frontal hairline, resembling a crown.
  • Palms and Soles Involvement:
    • May show hyperpigmented plaques or papules.
    • This is a classic clue for systemic syphilis.
  • Buschke-Ollendorff Sign:
    • Lesions are typically painless, but tender on deep palpation due to underlying vascular inflammation (endarteritis obliterans).
  • Moth-Eaten Alopecia:
    • Presents as non-scarring patchy hair loss on the scalp.
    • Distinguished from alopecia areata by irregular patch size and the presence of associated systemic signs.

Explanation of other options:

Trichotillomania (Option A): Typically shows uneven hair loss with hairs of varying lengths due to pulling; may show perifollicular hemorrhages.


Alopecia areata (Option B): Causes smooth, round patches of sudden hair loss but lacks associated skin or mucosal findings.


Malassezia (Option D): Commonly associated with seborrheic dermatitis or tinea versicolor; not linked with systemic signs or condyloma lata.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presents with a solitary skin nodule over his forearm and mild sensory loss localized along the distribution of the ulnar nerve. A skin biopsy was performed, and an intradermal lepromin test was conducted. Based on the clinical presentation and histological features shown in the image, which of the following is the most appropriate interpretation?
questions.solution:
• The patient presents with a single skin lesion, localized sensory loss, and histology revealing well-formed granulomas composed of epithelioid cells and Langhans giant cells findings that are consistent with tuberculoid leprosy, a form of paucibacillary leprosy.
  • A positive lepromin test further supports this diagnosis, indicating strong cell-mediated immunity, which is typical of the tuberculoid end of the leprosy spectrum.

Explanation of other options:

Lepromatous leprosy with a positive antigen test (Options B & D): This form shows a negative lepromin test due to poor cell-mediated immunity, and typically presents with multiple, poorly defined, symmetric lesions, not a solitary nodule.

Erythema nodosum leprosum (Option C): ENL is a painful, inflammatory reaction seen in lepromatous leprosy, characterized by multiple tender red nodules, not isolated, asymptomatic lesions.

Lepromatous leprosy with a negative antigen test (Option D): While a negative lepromin test is consistent, the clinical picture of a single well-defined lesion with localized nerve involvement does not fit lepromatous leprosy, which has diffuse, symmetric skin involvement.

questions.text: A skin biopsy was performed for a patient with a firm, indurated plaque. The histology is shown below. Based on the image, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical feature of a firm, indurated lesion along with squared-off edges on biopsy, giving a box-shaped appearance, points towards a diagnosis of Morphea (Localized Scleroderma).

Morphea (Localized Scleroderma):

  • A form of localized scleroderma characterized by areas of thickened, hardened skin.
  • Most commonly affects the trunk, but other sites can be involved.
  • May present as a single or multiple
  • Lesion Features:
    • Begins as a reddish (erythematous) plaque.
    • Over time, the centre of the plaque becomes atrophic and takes on an ivory-white appearance, often referred to as a central ivory scar.
    • The active edge of the lesion shows a violaceous or reddish border known as the lilac border, indicating ongoing disease activity.
  • Scalp Variant:
    • When it involves the frontoparietal scalp, it produces a linear, atrophic plaque extending downwards.
    • This presentation is termed En coup de sabre, resembling the mark of a sword.
  • Histopathology:
    • Skin biopsy reveals squared-off edges, often described as a box-like dermis.
    • The boxed appearance results from significant thickening and sclerosis of collagen within the reticular dermis, often extending into the subcutaneous fat septa.

Explanation of other options:

Lichen nitidus (Option B): Presents with tiny, flesh-colored papules; histology shows a "claw clutching a ball" appearance, not squared-off dermis.


Lichen planus (Option C): Characterized by violaceous, flat-topped papules with Wickham's striae; histology shows saw-toothing of rete ridges and band-like lymphocytic infiltrate, not sclerosis or squared-off edges.


Lichen amyloidosis (Option D): Presents with pruritic, hyperpigmented papules often on shins; histology shows amyloid deposits in papillary dermis, not collagen sclerosis or boxed dermis.


Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK559010/

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with reddish-orange scaly plaques on the body along with thickening of the palms and soles, as shown in the images below. A skin biopsy was taken and is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of orange-hued scaly plaques, palmoplantar keratoderma, and the characteristic histological finding of a checkerboard pattern of alternating orthokeratosis and parakeratosis strongly suggest Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris (PRP).

Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris (PRP):

  • Rare, chronic skin disorder presenting with reddish-orange scaly plaques, follicular involvement, and palmoplantar thickening.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Well-defined reddish-orange plaques with scaling.
    • Small keratotic papules around hair follicles (follicular keratosis).
    • Thickened, rough skin on palms and soles (palmoplantar keratoderma).
    • Areas of unaffected skin within lesions ("islands of sparing").
    • Nail involvement: thickening, discoloration.
    • Severe cases may progress to erythroderma.
  • Diagnosis & Investigations:
    • Clinical assessment based on typical appearance.
    • Skin biopsy:
      • Alternating areas of hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis (checkerboard pattern).
      • Distinctive "islands of sparing" within affected regions.
      • Salmon-colored background between papules.
    • Inherited forms: consider genetic testing.
    • Blood tests: rule out psoriasis, infections, or other causes.
  • Special Clinical Signs:
    • PRP Sandal Sign: Thickened, erythematous plaques on palms and soles.
    • Nutmeg Grater Papules: Rough, scaly papules over the knuckles.
  • Management:
    • Topical Treatments:
      • Emollients to improve hydration.
      • Corticosteroids for inflammation.
      • Vitamin D analogs for keratinocyte regulation.
    • Systemic Treatments:
      • Acitretin (commonly used first-line systemic agent).
      • Methotrexate or cyclosporine for extensive disease.
    • Biologics (for resistant cases):
      • TNF-alpha inhibitors.
      • IL-17 or IL-23 inhibitors.
    • Supportive Care:
      • Moisturizers, symptomatic relief, and UV-based therapies if indicated.

Explanation of other options:

Keratosis follicularis (Option B): Presents with greasy, crusted, warty papules, especially in seborrheic areas, not with orange plaques or checkerboard histology.


Follicular psoriasis (Option C): Involves follicular scaling and thickened palms/soles, but lacks the distinctive orange hue and checkerboard parakeratosis.


Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (Option D): Characterized by atypical lymphocytes with epidermotropism, Pautrier's microabscesses, and lacks the histological pattern seen in PRP.


Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK482436/

questions.text: A child presents with patchy hair loss. The microscopic image of the hair shaft shows fungal spores arranged within the shaft, as shown below. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The presence of arthroconidia arranged within the hair shaft is characteristic of Tinea Capitis caused by certain species of Trichophyton, such as T. tonsurans, T. violaceum, and T. schoenleinii.

Fungal Invasion Patterns of the Hair Shaft in Tinea Capitis:


1. Endothrix Invasion (Fungal Growth Inside the Hair Shaft)

  • Caused by:
    • Trichophyton tonsurans
    • Trichophyton violaceum
    • Trichophyton schoenleinii
  • Fungal elements grow within the hair shaft without damaging the outer cuticle.
  • Leads to weak, brittle hair that breaks near the scalp surface ("black dot" appearance).
  • No fluorescence was seen under Wood's lamp examination.

2. Ectothrix Invasion (Fungal Growth Around the Hair Shaft)

  • Commonly caused by:
    • Microsporum canis
    • Microsporum audouinii
  • Fungal spores coat the outer surface of the hair shaft, leading to cuticle damage.
  • Results in hair fragility, scaling, and patchy hair loss.
  • Some species may show fluorescence under a Wood's lamp.

3. Favus (Severe Chronic Form of Scalp Infection)

  • Caused by:
    • Trichophyton schoenleinii
  • Characterized by yellow, crusted lesions called scutula, giving a honeycomb-like appearance.
  • Leads to permanent hair loss with thin, brittle, and twisted hairs.
  • May result in scarring alopecia if left untreated.

Explanation of other options:

Microsporum (Option B): Typically causes ectothrix infection where fungal spores coat the outside of the hair shaft, not inside as seen in this case.

Epidermophyton (Option C): Affects skin and nails but does not infect hair shafts, so it cannot cause the endothrix pattern.

Candida (Option D): Causes mucocutaneous infections but does not invade hair shafts in this manner.

References: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK536909/

questions.text: A 22-year-old farmer presents with swelling over the foot and multiple discharging sinuses containing a white granular material. Microscopy of the discharge reveals gram-positive, branching filaments with a radiating appearance. What is the most likely organism responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of swelling with discharging sinuses containing white granules, along with microscopy showing gram-positive, branching filaments, point towards a diagnosis of actinomycetoma. The most likely organism responsible for this condition is Nocardia.

Cutaneous Nocardiosis:

  • Cause:
    • Skin infections caused by Nocardia species typically occur after trauma or direct contact with contaminated soil or water.
    • More common or severe in immunocompromised individuals.
  • Pathogenesis:
    • Entry through skin breaches (cuts, abrasions).
    • Local infection leads to abscesses, ulcers, or draining sinuses.
    • May spread via lymphatics (lymphocutaneous form) or form deeper granulomatous lesions (actinomycetoma).
  • Clinical Features:
    • Primary Cutaneous Form: Painless, slow-growing nodules, pustules, or ulcers; may discharge pus.
    • Lymphocutaneous Spread: Chain of nodules along lymphatic vessels.
    • Mycetoma (Chronic Form): Swelling with multiple sinuses draining yellow-white granules; commonly affects feet or hands.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Microscopy: Gram-positive, branching filaments; weakly acid-fast on modified staining.
    • Culture: Slow-growing colonies on blood agar or Sabouraud's dextrose agar.
    • Histopathology: Suppurative granulomas with visible filamentous structures.
  • Management:
    • First-line: Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX).
    • Severe/Disseminated Cases: Combination of antibiotics such as amikacin, imipenem, or linezolid.
    • Surgical Intervention: Drainage or excision for abscesses or extensive lesions.

Explanation of other options:

Sporothrix schenckii (Option A): Causes lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis with nodular lesions along lymphatics, not branching filaments or granular discharge.

Staphylococcus aureus (Option C): May cause chronic discharging sinuses in conditions like botryomycosis but lacks the filamentous appearance seen with Nocardia.

Histoplasma (Option D): Primarily causes pulmonary or disseminated fungal infections; it does not produce filamentous structures on gram stain or present with draining sinuses containing granules.

References:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK560872/

questions.text: A young girl presents with severe sunburns after only a few minutes of sun exposure. She also has marked freckling and pigmentation over sun-exposed areas, as seen in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The combination of severe sun sensitivity, freckling, and pigmentary changes over sun-exposed areas strongly suggests Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP).

Xeroderma Pigmentosum (XP):

  • Cause:
    • Rare inherited disorder with autosomal recessive
    • Due to a defective nucleotide excision repair (NER) pathway, leading to impaired DNA repair after UV exposure.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Skin Findings:
      • Marked sensitivity to sunlight (photosensitivity).
      • Early appearance of freckle-like pigmentation in sun-exposed areas.
      • Skin thinning (atrophy) and pigmentation abnormalities.
      • Premature skin ageing.
    • Ocular Involvement:
      • Sensitivity to light (photophobia).
      • Redness and irritation of the conjunctiva.
      • Risk of corneal ulcers and scarring.
    • Neurological Features (in some cases):
      • Developmental delay or cognitive impairment.
  • Cancer Risk: High risk of skin malignancies (e.g., basal cell carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, melanoma) at an early age.
  • Early diagnosis, strict photoprotection, and regular skin surveillance are crucial to reduce complications.

Explanation of other options:

Bloom Syndrome (Option A): Presents with photosensitivity but is also associated with short stature, characteristic facial features, and increased cancer risk; severe sunburns and marked freckling as in XP are not typical.


Warts (Option C): Caused by viral infections (HPV) and appear as raised verrucous lesions, not pigmentary changes or sun sensitivity.


Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (Option D): Photosensitivity occurs, but typically with systemic symptoms (joint pain, fatigue, malar rash), not isolated severe sunburn and freckling.

questions.text: A patient presents with a darkly pigmented, irregular, raised lesion on the skin, as shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The lesion is asymmetrical with irregular borders and color variation, consistent with malignant melanoma, a potentially aggressive skin cancer arising from melanocytes. 

Malignant Melanoma:

  • Origin: Arises from melanocytes, the pigment-producing cells of the skin.
  • Aggressiveness: Highly aggressive skin cancer with a strong tendency for local invasion and distant metastasis.
  • Clinical Identification - ABCDE Criteria:
    • A - Asymmetry: One half of the lesion does not match the other half.
    • B - Border: Edges are irregular, notched, or poorly defined.
    • C - Color: Uneven distribution of color, may include shades of black, brown, blue, red, or white.
    • D - Diameter: Lesion size is typically greater than 6 mm (about the size of a pencil eraser).
    • E - Evolution: Notable changes in size, shape, color, or associated symptoms such as itching or bleeding.
  • Importance: Early recognition using the ABCDE criteria is crucial for timely diagnosis and management.

Explanation of other options:

Basal Cell Carcinoma (Option A): Typically presents as a pearly, translucent nodule with central ulceration or telangiectasia, not a pigmented irregular lesion.


Squamous Cell Carcinoma (Option B): Usually appears as a scaly, crusted, erythematous plaque or nodule, often with ulceration, but lacks the characteristic pigmentation of melanoma.


Condyloma lata (Option D): Presents as broad, moist, flat papules in genital or perianal regions, unrelated to pigmented skin lesions

questions.text: A 35-year-old male agricultural worker from a rural area presents with a painless swelling over the foot, which has gradually increased in size over several months. On examination, multiple discharging sinuses with seropurulent material containing black granules are noted. The patient gives a history of frequently walking barefoot in the fields.What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture is suggestive of eumycetoma (Madura foot), characterized by chronic swelling, draining sinuses, and discharge containing granules, especially black granules. Walking barefoot in soil is a typical risk factor. Madurella mycetomatis is the most common fungal agent causing eumycetoma, particularly in tropical and subtropical regions.

Mycetoma (Madura Foot):

  • Chronic granulomatous infection involving subcutaneous tissues.
  • Characterized by swelling, draining sinuses, and discharge of grains.
  • Types:
    • Eumycetoma: Caused by fungi.
    • Actinomycetoma: Caused by filamentous bacteria.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Early Stage:
      • Painless subcutaneous nodule.
      • It may remain unnoticed for years.
    • Progression:
      • Enlarging mass with multiple sinus tracts.
      • Purulent discharge containing grains (black, white, or yellow, depending on the organism).
  • Complications:
    • Severe tissue destruction.
    • Bone involvement (osteomyelitis).
    • Risk of deformity and amputation if untreated.
  • Microscopic Features:
  • Histopathology: Suppurative granulomas with neutrophilic infiltration are common to both types.
  • Diagnostic Approach:
    • Tissue Biopsy: For direct visualization of organisms.
    • Microbiological Culture: Confirms fungal or bacterial cause.
    • Special Stains:
      • KOH mount for fungi.
      • Gram stain for bacteria.
    • Imaging:
      • X-ray or MRI to assess soft tissue and bone involvement.
  • Treatment:

Explanation of other options:

Curvularia lunata (Option B): Although Curvularia can rarely cause eumycetoma, it is much less common compared to Madurella mycetomatis, especially in endemic regions.

Nocardia brasiliensis (Option C): Causes actinomycetoma, the bacterial form of mycetoma, which typically produces white or yellow granules, not black ones.

Aspergillus fumigatus (Option D): Primarily associated with respiratory infections (e.g., aspergillosis) and is not a known cause of mycetoma or skin infections from walking barefoot.

Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC2840937/

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Behcet's Disease is false?
questions.solution:
Behcet's disease shows greater clinical resemblance to Crohn's disease, as both may present with features like oral ulcers, gastrointestinal symptoms, erythema nodosum, and joint involvement such as sacroiliitis. The association with ulcerative colitis is comparatively less frequent.

Behcet's Disease:

  • Behcet's disease is a chronic, relapsing inflammatory disorder characterized by systemic vasculitis affecting vessels of all sizes.
  • The exact cause is unknown, but it is believed to involve immune dysregulation, particularly neutrophilic inflammation.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Classic Triad:
      • Recurrent oral ulcers: Painful aphthous ulcers that may heal with scarring. (Option B)
      • Genital ulcers: Typically deeper, may be painless, usually do not scar.
      • Ocular involvement: Most often presents as relapsing uveitis, particularly posterior uveitis.(Option A)
    • Additional Systemic Features:
      • Non-erosive, oligoarticular arthritis (commonly affecting large joints like the knees).
      • Skin lesions such as erythema nodosum-like nodules and papulopustular eruptions.
      • Vascular involvement, including thrombosis due to systemic vasculitis.
      • Neurological, gastrointestinal, pulmonary, and cardiac complications can also occur in severe disease.
  • Diagnostic Clues:
    • Positive Pathergy Test: Development of papule or pustule at the site of minor skin trauma, reflecting skin hyperreactivity. (Option D)
    • Histopathology:
      • Features of vasculitis and thrombosis.
      • Prominent neutrophilic infiltrates, consistent with neutrophilic dermatosis.
  • Management:
    • Topical corticosteroids and local anaesthetics for mucosal lesions.
    • Systemic agents like colchicine for mucocutaneous symptoms.
    • Immunosuppressive therapies (e.g., corticosteroids, azathioprine, biologics) for severe systemic involvement.
